entry.title: Re: In Group Reporting , Data monitor is used for prepara...
entry.content:
Hello Naga

Group Reporting is used to consolidate all Entity Close data from various companies within the group, hence the term group closing or Consolidation. The Data Monitor is often referred as to Consolidation preparation.

Steps in the Data Monitor contains:  

* The Data Entry Process ( Collecting the data from various Companies)

*  Calculation of Anual Net Income ( that does not come from the Entity Close)

*  Data Validation ( You have Corporate Standards on the Data Quality)

* Adjustment Postings ( These contain correction postings from Entity Close or Standardized Postings to make adjustments to meet Corporate business guidelines)

* Currency Conversion ( Entites deliver data in their reporting currencies, but for Group to Consolidate these data you need to translate it to the Group Currency)

 

Consolidation Monitor

 

Here is where after Consolidation Preparation the Consolidation process starts

Interunit Elimination ( These are transactions that happen in between Companies ) They need to be neutralize cause they do not contribute to the Group Income as for an example and hence need to be taken off 

Consolidation of Investment ( This is where according to the Ownership Structure the Investments get eliminated against Capital and where the Income generated is calculated according to the ownership shares you have in each of the Companies from Group Perspective. 

The straight forward and easy case is if you own 100% of the company, but very likely this is not the case in a lot of large enterprises and hence not all profits are belonging to the group but also then to the minorities, that needs to be eliminated out. 

This is under the nutshell what Group Reporting does I hope this helps

 

BR Mike

entry.title: Re: Building Joule Skills for Sales Order Queries in S/4HANA Cloud - Part 1: Environment Setup
entry.content:
@BharathKumarVaddepalli 

Hi Bharath,

Good question ‚Äî in most cases, you can reuse the same destination as long as the System URI (base URL) and authentication method are the same for both APIs.

For example, if both your Sales Order and Purchase Order APIs come from the same S/4HANA Cloud tenant (e.g., https://myXXXX-api.s4hana.ondemand.com), you only need one destination. Joule or your app will simply call different API paths under that same base URL.

However, if the APIs belong to different systems (for example, one from S/4HANA Cloud and another from SAP Ariba, or from a different tenant), then you should create separate destinations, since each system has its own URI and credentials.

Hope that clears it up!

‚Äî Teng Teng

entry.title: How Job, Org Structure, Position & Employee Info Brew Together!
entry.content:
One of the biggest challenges in HR transformation projects? Explaining the difference between Organizational Structure and Job Structure‚Äîand how they connect to an employee.

In a recent workshop, I used simple analogies to make these concepts click for everyone. It sparked great conversations, and now I would love to share those insights with the wider community.

Position: The chair

Each Employee is assigned a position which reports to another Position forming an Org Chart

The chair holds a person, and it can also be vacant

Position sits in the company hierarchy 

Org Structure: Where Your Chair Is

Where the position sits in the company hierarchy (Where the Chair is placed in the Organization)

It‚Äôs the map of who reports to whom, which department you belong to, and how the business units are organized.

For example:

  • Business Unit: Corporate
  • Division: Finance
  • Department: Rewards
  • Position: Rewards Manager

Job Structure: What You Do in That Chair

Nature of the work the employee does, regardless of where they sit in the org chart. In our analogy,

So, while your position might be ‚ÄúRewards Manager,‚Äù under ‚ÄúFinance‚Äù Division, your job could be ‚ÄúCompensation Expert‚Äù under the Family ‚ÄúHuman Resource‚Äù

  • Function: Human Resource
  • Role: Compensation Expert
  • Tasks: Run the Annual Review Process

Where is it Used?

Org Structure: Reporting lines, budgeting, cost allocation, and workflow routing

Job Structure: Classification, reporting, and analytics e.g., how many people work in HR roles across the company. Used for talent management, succession planning, career paths

The combination of Org and Job Structure together reflects the reality of matrix organizations and cross-functional teams.

How Job, Org Structure, Position & Employee Info Brew Together!

Let‚Äôs imagine we‚Äôre making a cup of tea ‚Äî not just any tea, but one that represents how SAP SuccessFactors structures employee data.

Job:

This defines the core ingredients ‚Äî milk, water, ginger ‚Äî and the experience required to make it well. In SAP terms, this maps to:

  • Job Code
  • Job Level
  • Pay Grade
  • Pay Range

It‚Äôs the blueprint of what the tea (or role) is supposed to be.

Org Structure:

This tells us where the tea belongs in the broader beverage universe:

  • Business Unit: Herbal Hot Drinks
  • Division: Home Made
  • Department: Ginger

It‚Äôs how we categorize the tea in our caf√©‚Äôs hierarchy.

 

While the Job could classify ‚ÄúGinger Tea‚Äù under the Function ‚ÄúTea‚Äù, as per the given Org Structure, ‚ÄúGinger Tea‚Äù in reporting to the ‚ÄúHerbal‚Äù Team. So when Ginger Tea is out of stock, Procurement Team would seek approval from the ‚ÄúHerbal‚Äù rather then from the ‚ÄúTea‚Äù Department.

Position: The Actual Cup

This is the specific variant of the tea ‚Äî say, Ginger Tea with Brown Sugar or Ginger Tea with White Sugar or it could be even without Sugar. It pulls information from the job and org structure, and adds more variant such as:

  • Employee Class
  • Employee Type
  • Standard Weekly Hours
  • FTE (Full-Time Equivalent)

It‚Äôs the customized version of the job, ready to be served.

Employee Job Info: The Lemon Twist

Now, when someone drinks this tea (takes the position), they might add a personal touch ‚Äî like a squeeze of lemon such as:

  • Probation Status
  • Additional employee-specific attributes

It‚Äôs the final personalization that makes the tea uniquely theirs.

Summary

So yes ‚Äî your chair (position) might be in Finance, but your job (function) could be HR. And that‚Äôs perfectly okay.

Just like making a cup of ginger tea:

  • The Job ‚Äî milk, water, ginger, and the skill to brew it.
  • The Org Structure ‚Äî Herbal Hot Drinks > Home Made > Ginger.
  • The Position is the actual cup with a variant‚Äî Ginger Tea with Brown Sugar
  • The Employee Info is the lemon twist ‚Äî a personal touch

Together, they create a flavourful experience that reflects the flexibility and richness of modern organizations. And in SAP SuccessFactors, understanding this blend helps you serve up accurate data, meaningful analytics, and smooth workflows ‚Äî just like a well-brewed cup of tea.

entry.title: Re: How Landed Cost works in S/4Hana Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Dear @FERNANDOCH8,

There is no separate scope for landed cost.

Planned delivery costs (freight, insurance, customs‚Ä¶)  in the PO. Enter planned delivery costs as conditions on the purchase order (e.g., FGW1- freight).

 

At invoice time you can change planned amounts, the system posts them to inventory or price-diff/expense per configuration.

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0e602d466b99490187fcbb30d1dc897c/c370b6531de6b64ce10000000a174cb4.html

Unplanned delivery costs at invoice posting when the supplier invoice arrives, add unexpected charges (extra freight, handling, customs variances) as unplanned delivery costs directly on the invoice.

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/634261119fec4d58970471f2c4a9a740/8daa3fa8103347ef9830a8337f69f3bd.html

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3417121

Process for example:

  • Buyer adds freight/customs as planned conditions in Manage Purchase Orders.
  • Warehouse posts GR in Post Goods Receipt for Purchase Order.
  • AP posts the vendor invoice in Create Supplier Invoice ‚Äì Advanced, entering any unplanned delivery costs; system posts per configuration (distribute vs. separate G/L).

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Optimizing DMO Process During SAP S/4HANA Conversion
entry.content:
Optimizing DMO Process During SAP S/4HANA Conversion

When performing a system conversion to SAP S/4HANA using the Database Migration Option (DMO) of the Software Update Manager (SUM), minimizing downtime is one of the most critical success factors. This article explains a real-world case study of how downtime was optimized during a large-scale DMO project.

Project Overview

  • Source Database: Oracle, 5 TB (Linux)
  • Target Database: SAP HANA, 1.5 TB (Linux)
  • Objective: Conversion to SAP S/4HANA using DMO (DMOVES4)
  • Focus Area: Table split optimization and downtime reduction

SAP Downtime Optimization App

The SAP Downtime Optimization App proved extremely useful for analyzing and comparing different DMO runs.
After each DMO execution, SUM prompts for uploading the UPGANA.XML file. The app provides a detailed visualization of runtime distribution, helping identify performance bottlenecks and slow-moving tables.

First Conversion Run ‚Äî Baseline Benchmark

The initial DMO run was performed as a benchmark, using the standard migrate<*>dur.xml configuration file generated by SUM.

However, the downtime exceeded 3 days, primarily due to a long tail in table migration.
SUM (via SAPup) determines this ‚Äúlong tail‚Äù when R3load pair utilization drops significantly ‚Äî meaning a few large tables remain while others complete early, leaving many processes idle.

 

 

 

Observation:

  • Total downtime: ~3 days 2 hours (worst case)
  • Bottleneck: Large tables without proper splitting

 

 

Second Conversion Run ‚Äî Table Split Optimization

In the second DMO run, we reused the previous migrate<*>dur.xml file and performed manual table splitting for approximately 20 large tables based on SAP Note 3386079 ‚Äì SUM DMO scenarios: Manual Options for Table Splitting and Table Migration.

Example of Split Configuration:

SWW_PROPERTIES    segmentsize=0.02 

SRMPROTOCOL       segmentsize=0.01 

/IWFND/L_MET_COL  segmentsize=0.01 

PYD_D_AL          segmentsize=0.01 

SWWCNTP0          segmentsize=0.01 

INDX              segmentsize=0.01 

PPOIX             segmentsize=0.02 

PCL2              segmentsize=0.02 

SXMSCLUP          segmentsize=0.02 

PCL4              segmentsize=0.02 

P2RX_RT           segmentsize=0.02 

BALDAT            segmentsize=0.02 

DBTABLOG          segmentsize=0.02 

SWWLOGHIST        segmentsize=0.02 

COEP              segmentsize=0.02 

PPOPX             segmentsize=0.02 

FMIFIIT           segmentsize=0.02 

FMGLFLEXA         segmentsize=0.02 

SOFFCONT1         segmentsize=0.02

By adjusting segment sizes and applying parallel R3load tuning, we achieved a significant reduction in downtime.

 

 

 

 

 

Key Learnings

  1. Use SAP Downtime Optimization App:
    Continuously analyse each DMO run using UPGANA.XML to identify bottlenecks.
  2. Technical table data clean up.
  3. Update database statistics + oracle database parameter optimizations.
  4. Table Splitting is Critical:
    Manually split large tables based on SAP Notes to balance R3load utilization.
  5. Reuses migrate<*>dur.xml Files:
    Helps SUM optimize load distribution in subsequent runs.
  6. Monitor Long Tail Impact:
    Reduce idle R3load threads by ensuring even data distribution.
  7. Iterative Optimization:
    Multiple DMO test runs yield the best performance tuning results.

Outcome

Through manual table splitting and iterative fine-tuning, we achieved substantial downtime optimization ‚Äî reducing total conversion downtime from nearly 3 days to under 11 hours.

This practical approach not only enhanced efficiency but also provided valuable insight into how DMO behaves with large datasets, enabling smoother go-lives for future projects.

References

  • SAP Note 3386079 ‚Äì SUM DMO scenarios: Manual Options for Table Splitting and Table Migration
  • 936441 - Oracle settings for R3load based system copy
  • 1634908 - Reduce the number of entries from table SOFFCONT1
  • 1918774 - Performance issues when running an SAP Installation
  • SAP Downtime Optimization App

entry.title: What are the major challenges you faced while implementing Dynamics 365 Supply Chain Management?
entry.content:
Q: What are the major challenges you faced while implementing Dynamics 365 Supply Chain Management in a manufacturing setup?

We‚Äôre in the early stages of implementing Microsoft Dynamics 365 Supply Chain Management (SCM) in our manufacturing operations, and I‚Äôd like to learn from others who have gone through this journey. While Dynamics 365 SCM promises powerful capabilities like automation, predictive analytics, and real-time visibility, the actual implementation process often brings unexpected challenges‚Äîespecially in complex manufacturing environments.

For those who‚Äôve implemented D365 SCM, what were the biggest obstacles you encountered during or after deployment?

  1. Data Migration: How challenging was it to migrate legacy data from older ERP or MES systems into Dynamics 365 SCM? Were there issues with data consistency or structure?
  2. Customization & Configuration: Did you need to heavily customize workflows, or were the out-of-the-box features sufficient for your manufacturing processes?

It would also be great if you could share some best practices or lessons learned that helped your organization overcome these challenges. For example, did you involve cross-functional teams early in the project, or use Microsoft partners/consultants to streamline the process?

entry.title: Re: Release TR BC initial scope
entry.content:
Dear @Andrea_Gr,

  • Request Has Dependencies means your transport request (TR) can‚Äôt be released because it depends on other TRs that must be released (and usually imported) first. This is standard in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (CBC/BC transports).
  • The insert will be lost if you continue is a generic SAP data-loss warning. It appears if you have unsaved inserts/changes in the current screen. If you proceed, those unsaved UI changes are discarded, it doesn‚Äôt delete anything already in the TR.

More details in SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3462787

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Notification for SAP Cloud ALM Feature Approval
entry.content:
Hi Team,

In the implementation for SAP Cloud ALM, when we create Requirement we noticed that when a user request approval to the Requirement there is an automatic email to the approver. Additionally, we can also tag a user in the comment section whereby the approver can be tagged as well.

However, in Feature, we also need to get approval. Having said that, we didn't get any automatic notification to the approver nor we got the comment to tag for the approver. How can we achieve the same notification to the approver for Feature? We had this in ChaRM before in SOLMAN.

 

Kind Regards


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Notification for SAP Cloud ALM Feature Approval
entry.content:
SAP Solution Manager Change Documents has an approval workflow powered by PPF actions using multiple Business Partners and notifications. Different BPs can be assigned to different responsibilities in the CD in the same change. When the relevant BP needs to take action in the Change Document, they are notified by automated e-mails. 

SAP Cloud ALM is not intended as a 1-to-1 replication of SAP Solution Manager functionality. This includes comparing Change Deployment Management (CDM) and Change Request Management (ChaRM) functionality. CDM is a new way of working to manage and deploy code. More information can be found in 3427582.

Currently SAP Cloud ALM Features do not provide an approval workflow. Approval is possible for Production Deployment status only by using the additional Change Manager Role. More information can be found in Role Collection Recommendations. But there are no notifications for this approval. Currently SAP Cloud ALM Features can provide notifications as e-mails in these scenarios:

  • Feature assigned to the user
  • Import component version mismatch errors occurred
  • Transport checks Completed
  • Transport of Copies failed

Requirements and Features are also built with different processes in mind. Features don't provide a comment area. However, Features can be tagged in their "Additional Data" area. You could use a tag to flag it as requiring approval if you want to enforce a bespoke approval process.

If you wish to influence the future development of SAP Cloud ALM and provide direction to our Developers in relation to this topic, please use the options outlined in this KBA 3391676.

entry.title: Re: üî¥ Enterprise in Motion: Event-Driven Architecture Use Cases for Innovation and Agility
entry.content:
Hi @akuller ,

for inbound event consumption, start here in SAP Help: Creating an Event Consumption Model. And/or see the video on YouTube.

At this point I don't see too much value in creating standard (ie. pre-delivered) APIs for event consumption on the S/4HANA core side, i.e. in ABAP. For which events? For the standard events emitted by S/4HANA? The current use cases we're seeing are around non-S/4HANA events, e.g. from Subscription Billing, but not from another S/4HANA system. So the idea of the event consumptionmodel is to let the customer create/generate a tailored API for any event from anywhere - this is possible. And what would you do with a standard event anyway? All we could provide in standard would be a generic receiver that would eventually call a BAdI that would then have to do what you would want it to do. If building an Event Consumption Model is too much effort and a standard API would be better, we have to improve the ECM generation - we're open for feedback, as always. Also, in the end, you don't want a generic consumer, you always want to do something "special", so with that approach the framework we needed to provide would be too ridgid in the end, I'm afraid.
Anyway, check out the ECM.

Cheers, Christoph

entry.title: Re: Authorization in Sales Documents Based on Personnel
entry.content:
Good day @Publiccloud 

Thank you for your description and points raised.

To summarise, the authorisation on transactional objects, which in your scenario is the Sales Orders is not supported through standard authorisation fields in the sales business catalogs delivered in public cloud. The standard restriction framework covers:

  • Organisational attributes such as Sales Organisation, Division, Distribution Channel, etc., and
  • Data privacy constraints based on business roles.

However, individually, user visibility requires a clean-core extensibility workaround because the authorisation catalogues for apps like Manage Sales Orders or Displays Sales Orders do not include the responsible person as restriction fields.

Have a look at the following references and Blog for further details.

Authorization Concept, Authorization Management in Incentive and Sales Force Management, Authorization Concept in BOPF, Business Role ‚Äì Restriction Field Entity

Blog: Using Restrictions to Enhance User Authorizations in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SAP public cloud RAP Custom action Print pdf
entry.content:
Hi @JamesG

In summary, once you have created the print action in your RAP Behaviour Definition, the corresponding backend logic is implemented in the Behaviour Implementation Class (<your_behaviour_impl_class>) and not in the CDS entity itself.

The CDS entity (DEFINE ROOT VIEW ENTITY...) only holds structural definitions. It is not responsible for handling the action logic or storing transient content like a PDF binary.

Have a look at the following references and Blog for further details.

Comparing ABAP Restful Application Programming (RAP) model with the Cloud Application Programming (CAP) model, Business Object Implementation Types, ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model

Behavior Extensions, Defining Actions as Part of the Behavior Definition

Simplifying Attachment Downloads in RAP with CDS Views: A Step-by-Step Guide

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to Integrate SAP BTP Cloud Logging Service with SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS) Using SAML
entry.content:
Dear SAP Cloud Logging users,

We (SAP Cloud Logging team) cross-checked with BTP Security team on the general guidance: SAML and OIDC are both supported protocols. The general guidance to prefer OIDC is/was primarily targeting "Application Users" and not to the entire BTP.

As @shusei_sekiya rightly pointed out, SAP Cloud Logging does not support OIDC for external customers yet. The enablement of OIDC will follow the major version update for OpenSearch to 2.x (phase 3) which is planned for early December. So, the tentative timeline for OIDC would be early next year.

Details can be found is What's new with SAP Cloud Logging section.

Thanks, 
SAP Cloud Logging team

entry.title: Re: SAP B1 Web Client 2508
entry.content:
In 2508 we Choose From List control was introduced.
You can find it here:
https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_BUSINESS_ONE_WEB_CLIENT/e6ac71d18c7543828bd4463f77d67ff7/e060bc9215314528887f925e9b585733.html?locale=en-US&version=10.0_SP_2508

it enables multi-selection by setting the property "multiSelection" in the JSON:

"multiSelection": true

In order to process the returned values, the "change" event should be implemented.
I tested successfully the following code:

async onTestMultiSelect(oEnv, oEvent) {
      const value = oEvent.getParameter('value'); // Object with selected items
      const oView = await oEnv.ActiveView();
     
      if (value && typeof value === 'object' && Object.keys(value).length > 0) {
        // Extract item codes from the object structure
        const itemCodes = Object.values(value).map(item => item.value);
        const itemNames = Object.values(value).map(item => `${item.value} - ${item.rowValue.ItemName}`);
       
        const message = `You selected ${itemCodes.length} item(s): ${itemNames.join(' ')}`;
        await oEnv.showMessageBox("Multi-Selection Result", message);
       
        // Update the static text display
        const currentData = await oView.getCustomizedData("data");
        currentData.SelectedItems = itemCodes.join(', ');
        await oView.setCustomizedData(currentData, "data");
       
        // Update the CFL control value to show selected items
        const oCFL = await oView.ChooseFromList("fXbi5iHiSdn2iyMkeyFpgx");
        await oCFL.setValue(itemCodes.join(', '));
      } else {
        await oEnv.showMessageBox("Multi-Selection Result", "No items selected");
       
        // Clear the CFL value if nothing selected
        const oCFL = await oView.ChooseFromList("fXbi5iHiSdn2iyMkeyFpgx");
        await oCFL.setValue("");
      }
    }

 You can also use a dialog form as a pop-up form, and design if with any logic you desire.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_BUSINESS_ONE_WEB_CLIENT/e6ac71d18c7543828bd4463f77d67ff7/6c4ad8a9fc6748c0a678f1463dea9ffe.html?locale=en-US&version=10.0_SP_2508

-> Similar struggle I encountered with the Rewards and Recognition. The case there is that employees who has a disciplinary action in the previous 6 month shouldn't be eligible for SPOT award. In order to store data on those disciplinary actions we have a custom MDF object, and then in the business rule (Rewards and Recognition scenario) I wanted to build the logic to look at the effective date of the disciplinary actions from that MDF, saying that if effective date of the actions is earlier than previous 6 month then employee is eligble, else employee is not eligible (this seems to work), and an additional condition would be OR if employee doesn't have any disciplinary actions then employees is eligible (and this second condition I can't make it work).

Anyone had similar cases maybe, or managed to build a rules using the data from MDF object, that would actually work? Or should I maybe use "Rules for MDF Objects" scenario for the business rule in order to have it functioning properly?

Many thanks!

entry.title: SAP RPT-1: Ready-to-Use AI for Structured Data
entry.content:
Hi all,

as you may have heared, SAP recently introduced RPT-1 (Relational Pre-Trained Transformer).  To explore how well the model will work and if it is able to return different outputs, I integrated it into a small SAP CAP application. My choosen dataset contains historical data with sample customer pizza orders (order day, order time, pizza type, order quantity, etc.).

The goal: predict each customer‚Äôs next order day and next pizza type üçï.

RPT-1 in Action 

A standard Fiori Elements list report displays the historical data that serves as input. When the user selects a customer and clicks ‚ÄúTrigger Prediction,‚Äù the CAP backend sends data to the RPT-1 API and receives the predicted results. These are then shown in charts within a dialog.

Short program flow overview:

  1. CAPreads historical order data from (HANA-) DB
  2. Backend constructs the payload that RPT-1 expects. (API key and endpoint details can be found in the official documentation.)
  3. Model returns predicted columns (next_day, next_pizza). These fields must exist in the data structure as well
  4. Backend merges historical data and prediction results
  5. Frontend visualizes both predicted sets using VizFrame charts

I found it very useful to try out RPT-1 in the Playground first before building a full application. Here you can experiment with your dataset and understand the prediction behavior as well as how you might need to adjust your data set to get the desired outcomes.

If you are are curious like me how that works in CAP, I have listed my doings below:

Set up your environment - Use SAP Business Application Studio (BAS) or VS Code with the SAP Fiori and CAP extensions installed. Create a new CAP project or a Full-Stack application using the Productivity Tools

Prepare your data - Create a CSV file with columns like customer, order_day, pizza_type, quantity, etc., and deploy it to your database (SQLite or SAP HANA using cds deploy --to hana / sqllite: db.sqlite

Get access to RPT-1 - Use the API endpoint: https://rpt.cloud.sap/api/predict The API token is available on the SAP RPT-1 documentation page (after logging in with your S-user)

Prepare the payload & Call the RPT-1 API  - I tried to get the payload in the form like mentioned in the documentation

const historic = await SELECT.from(HistoricalData);  
const trainRows = historic
      // optionally focus payload on one customer:
      .filter(r => !focusCustomer || r.customer_id === focusCustomer)

      .map(r => ({
        customer_id: r.customer_id,
        pizza_name: r.pizza_name,
        order_day: r.order_day,
        next_order_day: r.next_order_day,
        next_pizza_name: r.next_pizza_name
      }));‚Äã

Screenshot from expected payload:

Do not forget to provide the data set which you want to predict (normally that is all in your initial data set and marked with "[PREDICT]", but to explicitly show it, I also hardcoded one line of data where I want to get the prediction results)

  const predictRows = [
      { customer_id: focusCustomer, pizza_name: "Margherita", order_day: "Thu", next_order_day: "[PREDICT]", next_pizza_name: "[PREDICT]" }
    ]

Constructed Payload in the service.js file

 const payload = {
      rows: [...trainRows, ...predictRows],
      index_column: "customer_id"
  };‚Äã

Once these preparation steps are done , I used axios to call the above described API route (remember to get you API Token)

    try {
      const response = await axios.post(API_URL, payload, {
        headers: {
          "Authorization": `Bearer ${TOKEN}`,
          "Content-Type": "application/json",
        },
      });
     console.log("Prediction result:", JSON.stringify(response.data, null, 2));
    } catch (error) {
      console.error("RPT-1 error:", error.response?.data || error.message);
      };
    }

Once the API call was successful, the API returns a json object (including your historical send data along with the prediction result). Here an extract of the payload I received: 

Prediction result: {
  "prediction": {
    "id": "782d5f80-0dd3-4b06-a589-985cfe5a41db",
    "metadata": {
      "num_columns": 4,
      "num_predict_rows": 3,
      "num_predict_tokens": 6,
      "num_rows": 24
    },
    "predictions": [
      {
        "customer_id": "C004",
        "next_order_day": [
          {
            "confidence": null,
            "prediction": "Sat"
          }
        ],
        "next_pizza_name": [
          {
            "confidence": null,
            "prediction": "Seafood Special"
          }
        ]
      },
      {
        "customer_id": "C004",
        "next_order_day": [
          {
            "confidence": null,
            "prediction": "Thu"
          }
        ],
        "next_pizza_name": [
          {
            "confidence": null,
            "prediction": "Margherita"
          }
        ]
      },
      {
        "customer_id": "C004",
        "next_order_day": [
          {
            "confidence": null,
            "prediction": "Sun"
          }
        ],
        "next_pizza_name": [
          {
            "confidence": null,
            "prediction": "Margherita"
          }
        ]
      }
    ]
  },
  "delay": 272.4773660004139,
  "aiApiRequestPayload": {
    "prediction_config": {
      "target_columns": [
        {
          "name": "next_order_day",
          "placeholder_value": "[PREDICT]",
          "task_type": "classification"
        },
        {
          "name": "next_pizza_name",
          "placeholder_value": "[PREDICT]",
          "task_type": "classification"
        }
      ]
    },
    "rows": [ //rows which where present here in my historical data
      {
        "customer_id": "C004",
        "pizza_name": "Seafood Special",
        "order_day": "Sun",
        "next_order_day": "Sat",
        "next_pizza_name": "Margherita"
      }, ... // more rows

In case you care only about the preduction result (for further processing) you will find that in: 

predictions = response.data.prediction.predictions
"predictions": [
      {
        "customer_id": "C004",
        "next_order_day": [
          {
            "confidence": null,
            "prediction": "Sat"
          }
        ],
        "next_pizza_name": [
          {
            "confidence": null,
            "prediction": "Seafood Special"
          }
        ]
      },
      {
        "customer_id": "C004",
        "next_order_day": [
          {
            "confidence": null,
            "prediction": "Thu"
          }
        ],
        "next_pizza_name": [
          {
            "confidence": null,
            "prediction": "Margherita"
          }
        ]
      },
      {
        "customer_id": "C004",
        "next_order_day": [
          {
            "confidence": null,
            "prediction": "Sun"
          }
        ],
        "next_pizza_name": [
          {
            "confidence": null,
            "prediction": "Margherita"
          }
        ]
      }
    ]

Eventhough we have the predicted results,  in most of the cases we want to combine the hostorical data with predicted results, to display a kind of graphical trend / relation. 

In my case, to get the shown graphs which could be the next potential order day and the next potential pizza, I combined the data in an object and returned it to my Handler.js file. To get the desired outcome within the graphical illustration later in the front-end I returned the predicted and historical data like this: 

let returnObject = {
      customerId: focusCustomer,
      history: {
        byDay: historyByDay,       // e.g., bind to series ‚ÄúHistory‚Äù
        byPizza: historyByPizza
      },
      predictions: {
        rows: predsForCustomer,    // raw rows if you want a details table
        top: { day: topDay, pizza: topPizza }, // for highlight
        byDay: predictedByDay,     // e.g., 2nd series ‚ÄúPredicted‚Äù on the weekday chart
        byPizza: predictedByPizza  // e.g., overlay or stacked series on pizza chart
      }
    }

Visualize the results - The returned JSON I used as a basis to construct the graphical illustration in the front end. In the Handler.js I filled a JSON model with the data recieved from the backend (above JSON object) and wired the XML Fragement around it

Conclusion 

Including RPT-1  in a CAP app seemed very smooth. Especially all the  important information (like API Keys, API Route, Payload Structure) was easy to find. During the development I still had in the back of my mind when to use other SAP provided services which  seems to be similar (like Data Attribute Reccomondation for instance). I know other services are more focused on the full ML life cycle (i have my own model, training iterations, etc.) but sometimes I am wondering with all the available services, which tool to choose from the big toolbox SAP provides. 

From a first sight, I feel that with such a quick integration option like with RPT-1 I can cover 70-80% of use cases. At least to get accurate results in a very short time. Still I believe for data specific use cases, where I want to use my own trained model, Data Attribute Recommondation would be still my preferred option.

Please share your opinion as well for which use cases you use which kind of services

Since this is my first SAP Community article, I‚Äôd be happy to receive your feedback. Let me know in the comments how you see RPT-1 and the new doors it opens for enterprise AI.

entry.title: Re: Delta (statistical) depreciation areas missing in SAP...
entry.content:
Hi @maekman

Your question did not get to me. Please ensure you use the @links to ensure it gets to the intended person.

To summarise, in public cloud, Sweden does not have pre-delivered statistical depreciation areas because SAP‚Äôs local template assumes that the difference between local tax and book depreciation is handled manually in accordance with Swedish legal and accounting requirements.

Since configuration activity 105494 is display-only in public cloud, you cannot create a new depreciation area such as statistical deltas. Considering the public cloud adheres to a clean-core approach, it sets localisation boundaries, meaning all additional statistical areas must either:

  • Be part of the delivered localisation, or
  • Be handled manually through reporting and adjustment postings in the General Ledger (AA subledger alignment).

Below is a guided step to handle the posting.

First, you need to identify the Difference Using the Standard Report. In the Asset History Sheet app, run the report for your company code and fiscal year-end. Compare Depreciation Area 15, which is Local T and Depreciation Area 32 which is Book. Then extract the delta, this is the amount to post for each asset.

Second, is to create a Manual Adjustment Posting in the Post General Journal Entries app. Enter your Swedish company code, enter Posting Date. Debit/Credit the relevant depreciation expense accounts, assign the posting to Ledger Group=2L to restrict impact to local GAAP only.

Third, is to reconcile in Asset Accounting subledger by using the Manage Fixed Assets app. Check the depreciation posted for each area. Use your manual journal as a reconciliation item between Depreciation Area 15 and 32. Attach the journal entry ID in your year-end workpaper for audit.

Optionally (step 4), you can automate reporting. To do that, created a Custom Analytical Query based on CDS view I_AssetBalanceCube. Add DepreciationArea and AmountType dimensions. Filter Area 15 and 32, calculate delta through a formula. This report gives you a ready dataset for your year-end manual posting.

Next step is maintaining the G/L Accounts. Either you create or reuse G/L accounts for Expense, Accumulated Depreciation, or maintain these in your Chart of Accounts.

 

Apologies for the wrong link.

Have a look at the following references for further details.

Example: Parallel Accounting and the Derived Depreciation Area, Parallel Accounting in Asset Accounting,

Depreciation Areas, Parallel Accounting, Ledger Scenarios, Depreciation Posting Run

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: How to handle fixed asset impairment in S/4HANA Public Cloud (US GAAP)?
entry.content:
We are implementing SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and we want to know how to handle impairment of fixed assets.

Our accounting principle is USAP(US GAAP), and in depreciation area 34(Book Depreciation), it seems that asset revaluation is not allowed. In on-premise or private cloud, we can set the flag "Post Revaluation" in transaction code OAYR, but in S/4HANA Public Cloud this option is not available.

As an alternative, we are considering unplanned depreciation, but we understand that impairment and unplanned depreciation are conceptually different.
Should we use unplanned depreciation, or is there another recommended way to reflect the impairment loss under US GAAP?

Thank you for your insights.

entry.title: PY-TH: Navigating the Tax Deduction Maze of Diverse Employee Funds
entry.content:
The Thailand Payroll Team is preparing for the implementation of a new government scheme, the Employee Welfare Fund (EWF), to comply with the act issued by the Ministry of Labour.

Although the fund was initially scheduled to affect all companies in Thailand starting October 2025, the Thai cabinet approved and Ministry of Labour announced a one-year postponement in August 2025. This crucial decision shifts the mandatory compliance date to October 2026 and provides the payroll team with additional time to fully understand the EWF and prepare for its operational management.

Before diving into the details of the EWF, it is essential to first establish why this new compliance is so important for the Thailand payroll function. 

The Diverse Employee Fund in Net Income Calculation

When an employer pays salary to employees, the payroll administrator must calculate the net taxable income and the tax amount to determine the final net income (Net Pay) that employees receive at the end of month. This is the high level formula used to calculate Net Income.

I mapped the net pay formula to the pay slip for better understanding and highlighted the fund contribution amount (No.4 in the picture) in this blog.

Most companies in Thailand are required to contribute the Provident Fund and Social Security fund. The term "most" is used because the Provident fund is optional for employers, and public sector companies are excluded from Social Security Fund as they have their own health benefits. Nevertheless, if your company falls under this category, your payroll team must manage these two funds to comply with Thai law. There are other types of funds in Thailand that your payroll team needs to manage. I categorized the Fund in Thailand related to permanent employee in three groups.

Group 1 - Most companies in Thailand must  submit information to the government departments and Fund managers after payroll calculation. Social Security Fund of Social Security Office (SSO) , Provident Fund (PVD) , Student Loan Fund (SLF) , Worker's Compensation Fund Social Security Office (WCF) , Employee Welfare Fund (EWF).

Group 2 - These funds apply to specific industries. If your company operates as public sector organization or private school, you will need to manage these funds. Government Pension Fund (GPF) , Government Permanent Employee Registered Provident Fund (GPEF), Private Teacher Aid Fund.

Group 3 - These are mutual funds that employees invest in themselves. Payroll team needs to take action when employees declare their investments for tax exemption purposes. Examples include the Retirement Mutual Fund (RMF) and Thai Environment Social Governance Fund (Thai ESG) - SAP Note 3409981 - for tax year 2025 onward. In the previous tax year, Long Term Equity Fund (LTF) and Super Saving Fund (SSF) were also part of tax exemption schemes. For more details, SAP Payroll Thailand.

This is an overview information of the diverse employee funds in Thailand. Next we dive into what we started, Employee Welfare Fund (EWF). We developed and released to our customers in August 2025 before the original effective date in October 2025, and we will continue to keep it updated for the new effective date of October 2026. To increase Thailand payroll team confidence and understand solution and how to configure.

Employee Welfare Fund Payroll Process Guide

1. Legal and Calculation Requirement Monthly process Both the employee and the employer equal monthly contributions at EWF's fixed rate of employee's based income.

Contribution Formula:

Submission Deadline: The Payroll team must submit the EWF Contribution Report (SKL3) and the corresponding contribution amount to EWF by the 15th of the following month.

2. Data Maintenance in the Payroll Solution

Defining Based Income Amount (No 2), the based income amount is calculated by assigning relevant income Wagetypes to Cumulation Class no 44. These assinged Wagetypes will be summed up to form the basis for the EWF calculation.

This is company or business specific requirement. The Thailand payroll team needs to confirm with Employee Welfare Fund which income types are defined as the based income. Check your income Wagetypes and ensure they are configured in Cumulation Class no 44. (using table V_T512W_D or report program RPDLGA20)

EWF's Monthly Contribution Rate (No 3), The EWF contribution rate is announced by the Ministry of Labour. This rate is maintained in a standard system table (V_T511K). The system accessed this rate when the Wagetypes MW01 is maintained in the employee data and calculates during the payroll run. Any legal changes to the rate will be released on the SAP Note for you to apply.

Identifying EWF Members, Only employees who are active EWF members are included in the calculation. The Payroll team must maintain the membership data using the standard Wagetype MW01 which set in Processing Class No 68. The system will only process contributions for employees who have this data maintained in Infotype 0014Recurring Payment/Deduction.

Note: If the Wagetype does not appear in the payroll log verify that Processing Class 68 of MW01 is set correctly. (the default setting should be correct).

3. Monthly Payroll Calculation

During the monthly payroll run, the system executes a function for the EWF calculation. 

Payroll Function: The system calculates the final EWF contribution amount the specific payroll function name THEWF.

Verification: The Payroll team can verify the calculation result and breakdown in the payroll log. (See SAP Note 3598469 for detailed payroll calculation information).

 

4. Reporting and Submission

The final step is generating the required report for official submission. One key information in the report is Business Category that you should configure in V_T7THBR table.

 

Report Generation: The payroll team can generate the official report using the transaction code PC00_M26_CEWF. This program generate the result in ALV layout and PDF format. More detail information for report SAP Note 3628546

 

The configuration guide and solution information will help your Thailand Payroll Team be ready to operate Employee Welfare Fund (EWF) for your employees in October 2026. Should there be any legal changes before October 2026, the solution will be updated and released on SAP Regulatory Change Manager. For more details about HCM Thailand, refer to SAP Regional Collaboration Workzone Groups - Thailand.

HCM Payroll #HCM Payroll Thailand Localization

entry.title: Hire Template Configuration: Supported MDF Object Types and Implementation Guidelines for Onboarding
entry.content:
Introduction: 

When configuring the New Hire Data Review or Personal Data Collection pages in SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding, we observe that data from effective-dated custom MDF objects does not propagate correctly to Employee Central.

In some cases, the following issues may occur:

  • Data entered in Onboarding does not appear in the Manage Pending Hires (MPH) page.
  • Information captured during Onboarding is missing or overwritten once the candidate is converted to an employee.
  • Custom fields linked to effective-dated MDF objects fail to display or save values correctly in Onboarding forms.
  • Unexpected behavior or data inconsistencies are noticed when using effective-dated entities that are originally configured in Employee Central but reused in Onboarding.

Why do we see such data inconsistencies?

This behavior typically occurs because SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding supports only non-effective dated MDF objects, due to its dependency on external user context, unlike Employee Central where effective-dated entities are supported.

What is the Supported Configuration in Onboarding?

  • Onboarding users (external candidates) do not yet have a full employee profile or time context as in Employee Central.
  • Hence the supported type is Non-Effective Dated Custom MDF Objects only.
    How to add this Configuration:
  • When defining the MDF object under Configure Object Definitions, set Effective Dating to None.
  • Add the object to the New Hire Template ‚Üí Data Review Page or Personal Data Collection Page.

Why Onboarding Does Not Support Effective-Dated Entities:

  • Onboarding operates within the external user context, where users are not yet fully active employees.
  • Effective-dated entities require Employee Central user context to manage date-driven records.
  • Since the Onboarding process is provisional, effective-dating logic cannot be applied.
  • Once the user transitions to EC, effective-dated MDF Objects can be used for ongoing employee data management.

What is the recommended approach when configure New Hire Templates including custom MDF Objects for Onboarding?

  • Always use non-effective-dated MDF Objects for Onboarding.
  • If you already have effective-dated custom objects in New Hire Template (Onboarding):
    • Create a duplicate non-effective-dated object (copy the structure but change Effective Dating ‚Üí None).
    • Map this object in the New Hire Template under the relevant section (Data Review or Personal Data Collection).
    • Keep the EC effective-dated version for post-hire data synchronization.

What behaviour change was introduced in 2H 2025 Release to avoid using effective dated custom objects in New Hire Template:

  • Previously, there was no error message to inform the administrator that the Hire Template doesn't support non-effective dated custom MDF objects.
  • Currently, an error message informs the administrator that the Hire Template supports only non-effective dated custom MDF objects. 
  • Guide link for reference: Minor Visual Changes in 2H 2025 | SAP Help Portal
Frequently Asked Questions:
  • If we change the effective dating setting from ‚ÄúEffective-Dated‚Äù to ‚ÄúNone,‚Äù will existing data be lost?
    The data should not be lost when effective dating is set to ‚ÄúNone‚Äù. However, we would recommend creating a new object and avoid making changes to the existing object.

  • After switching to ‚ÄúNone‚Äù for effective dating, will the custom MDF objects stop mapping correctly to the Employee Profile?
    The data flow to Employee Profile will not be withheld. Since this is the recommended approach, there will not be any data loss when propagating to EC.

  • If we are currently using effective-dated MDF entities without encountering any issues. Under what specific scenarios or configurations do data loss or data propagation issues occur?
    There is no definitive scenario for which the data wipe out issues occur and since we do not support effective dated custom MDF Objects in Onboarding it is not possible to for us to determine the root cause. The correct way to configure the new hire template is available in the guide: Configuring Hire Template for Access New Hire

entry.title: Re: Timeouts When Maintaining Large Business Roles in S/4...
entry.content:
Dear @Mike_vanIngen,

  • The timeouts you‚Äôre seeing are a known limitation when a single business role contains a very large number of business catalogs. SAP‚Äôs official guidance is to split the mega-role into several smaller roles and avoid editing roles with 1000+ catalogs.

Please check SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3648696

 

  • Create From Template‚Äùdoesn‚Äôt accept a user-defined upload file. It‚Äôs only for SAP-delivered Business Role Templates (you pick a template in the app and the system copies its catalogs/restrictions). If you want to reuse a role you built, use Download/Upload Business Roles (XML) or transport it via Software Collections not Create From Template.

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/53e36b5493804bcdb3f6f14de8b487dd/8980ad05330b4585ab96a8e09cef4688.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/53e36b5493804bcdb3f6f14de8b487dd/a58f69585339484aa204cf0321cab2cd.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/53e36b5493804bcdb3f6f14de8b487dd/83c1cd62666f48c68d93f2fdeae1ae95.html

My suggestion and practical workarounds:

  • Replace the single super-role with a ‚Äúbundle‚Äù of smaller roles Break catalogs by LoB (e.g., Finance, MM, SD, WM, Analytics), by scope item groups, or by technology (GUI/Fiori) depending on how you troubleshoot.
  • Use tooling to find missing authorizations instead of blanket access Display Authorization Trace app activate a trace for the affected business user, have them reproduce the issue, then review failed checks and fix just the needed catalogs/restrictions.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/53e36b5493804bcdb3f6f14de8b487dd/79b3c9b7701248fe83b81d4b15134e8d.html

  • IAM Information System + Business Catalogs: look up an app ‚Üí see its required business catalogs and scope-item ties, then adjust roles precisely. This is SAP‚Äôs recommended route after upgrades when tiles ‚Äúdisappear‚Äù. More details in SAP Note‚Äôs:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2602149

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3462922

  • SAP‚Äôs own guidance after upgrades: review and adapt business roles rather than grant everything. More details on SAP Community:

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/review-and-adapt-business-roles-after-a-major-upgrade-in-the-sap-s-4hana/ba-p/13636083

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Customer Payments ‚Äì Transition and Future with APIs
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Customer Payments - Transition and Future with APIs

SAP has transitioned SAP Cloud for Customer Payments into maintenance mode and removed it from the price list (as of September 2, 2024). The solution will continue to be supported for existing customers under active contracts, but no further development or investments are made. Customers are encouraged to transition to the new API-based approach in SAP S/4HANA Cloud and On-Premise/Private Cloud.

Accounts receivable processes today are often costly, manual, and time-consuming. Many businesses face delays in cash collection, lack of transparency for their customers, and high operational costs for invoice and payment handling.

With the new S/4HANA APIs, SAP enables customers and partners to build modern customer-facing portals that accelerate the invoice-to-cash process and support automated cash collection. These portals empower end customers with self-service capabilities, reducing manual workload while improving the customer experience.

Capabilities Enabled by S/4HANA APIs

Using the APIs already available in S/4HANA On-Premise, Private Cloud, and Public Cloud businesses can:

APIs for Electronic Bill Presentment and Payment

  • Pay & manage bills: Select open items, create payments (via direct debit or credit card when SAP Digital Payments Add-on is integrated), view or cancel payments in process
  • Display account statements: View and download all items for a specific time period for the customer invoice, credit memo, and / or incoming payment(s)

Other APIs

  • Match payments with invoices: Improve reconciliation through payment matching
  • Create and manage payment advice: Issue or cancel payment advice efficiently
  • Make ad-hoc payments: Support payments on account or down payment requests
  • Manage account master data: View and update account and master data directly

These capabilities can be embedded into custom-built portals or integrated into existing customer-facing portals, offering flexibility for each company‚Äôs unique landscape.

This new API approach is not a one-to-one successor, but provides greater flexibility:

  • APIs are released for S/4HANA On-Premise, Private Cloud, and Public Cloud (from release 2508.02)
  • Customers can build their own portals, integrate into existing ones, or leverage partner-built portals
  • Partners are actively working with SAP to deliver ready-to-use solutions based on these APIs

Partner Solutions: Ready-to-Use Customer Payment Portals

To help customers accelerate adoption, SAP partners already offer pre-built customer payment and self-service portals leveraging the new APIs.

Kumulon ‚Äì KUMOsphere B2B Payment Portal

Kumulon delivers a cloud-native, template-based portal built on SAP BTP with full support for SAP‚Äôs latest payment APIs.

  • Real cloud services, no legacy code ‚Äì innovative SAP Cloud technologies only
  • Flexible templates ‚Äì adapt quickly to customer needs while jumpstarting projects
  • Secure integration ‚Äì SAP Cloud Connector ensures safe on-premise-to-cloud connectivity
  • Flexible deployment ‚Äì operate in your own BTP environment or as SaaS on Kumulon‚Äôs BTP

üîó KUMOsphere ‚Äì B2B Payment Portal on SAP Store

Acuiti Labs ‚Äì Customer Self Care and Payment Portal

Acuiti Labs offers a SaaS-based self-service and payment portal for S/4HANA Private and Public Cloud (Sales Billing/FI-AR) leveraging the S/4HANA APIs.

  • Customer self-service portal ‚Äì empowers end customers to manage invoices and payments directly
  • Cross-solution experience ‚Äì already proven in BRIM (FI-CA), Subscription Billing, and Q2C portals
  • Accelerated go-live ‚Äì prebuilt solution reduces implementation effort

üîó Acuiti Labs Customer Portal on SAP Store

Learn More

APIs for Electronic Billing and Presentment ‚Äì S/4HANA On-Premise (OP), Private Cloud

  • All APIs part of the Electronic Billing and Presentment scope are shipped via SAP Note 3505741
  • For other required APIs outside the package, please see also the SAP Business Accelerator Hub for more details, for example: Managing Payment Advice is available, see Payment Advice (A2X).
  • For more information, visit the SAP Help Portal.

APIs for EBPP Payment Request ‚Äì S/4HANA Public Cloud

  • Please see the SAP Business Accelerator Hub for the available EBPP Payment Request APIs.
  • For other required APIs outside the package, please see also the SAP Business Accelerator Hub for more details, for example:
    • Match payments with invoices & Create and manage payment advice, Payment Advice.
    • Make ad-hoc payments, Journal Entry -Post
    • Manage account master data, Business Partner
    • Customer account balance, Accounting Document - Read
  • For more information, visit the SAP Help Portal.

Summary

SAP Cloud for Customer Payments is moving into maintenance mode, and the future lies in API-driven, flexible customer payment portals. Customers can now:

  • Plan their transition to S/4HANA API-based solutions
  • Either build their own portals or leverage ready-to-use partner solutions from the SAP Store

This shift gives businesses greater flexibility, faster innovation, and improved customer experiences in the accounts receivable process.
